indications:
Indications 
(From Carbamazepine and related antiepileptics: British National Formulary)
Carbamazepine and related antiepileptics
name: OXCARBAZEPINE
cautions:
Cautions hypersensitivity to carbamazepine (see also Antiepileptic Hypersensitivity
Syndrome); avoid abrupt withdrawal; hyponatraemia (monitor plasma-sodium concentration in patients at risk), heart failure (monitor body-weight), cardiac conduction disorders; avoid in acute
porphyria (section 9.8.2); interactions: see Interactions in section
4.8.1 and Appendix 1 (oxcarbazepine)Blood, hepatic, or skin disorders Patients or their carers should be told how to recognise signs of
blood, liver, or skin disorders, and advised to seek immediate medical
attention if symptoms such as lethargy, confusion, muscular twitching,
fever, rash, blistering, mouth ulcers, bruising, or bleeding develop
side-effects:
Side-effects nausea, vomiting, constipation, diarrhoea, abdominal
pain; dizziness, headache, drowsiness, agitation, amnesia, asthenia,
ataxia, confusion, impaired concentration, depression, tremor; hyponatraemia;
acne, alopecia, rash, nystagmus, visual disorders including diplopia; less commonly urticaria, leucopenia; very rarely hepatitis, pancreatitis, arrhythmias, blood disorders, multi-organ
hypersensitivity  (see also Antiepileptic Hypersensitivity
Syndrome),
systemic lupus erythematosus, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, and toxic
epidermal necrolysis; hypertension and hypothyroidism also reported;
suicidal ideation
doses:
Initially 300 mg twice daily increased according to response
in steps of up to 600 mg daily at weekly intervals; usual dose range
0.6–2.4 g daily in divided doses; child 6–18 years, 8–10 mg/kg daily in 2 divided doses increased according
to response in steps of up to 10 mg/kg daily at weekly intervals (in
adjunctive therapy, maintenance dose approx. 30 mg/kg daily); max.
46 mg/kg daily in divided doses

In adjunctive therapy, the dose
of concomitant antiepileptics may need to be reduced when using high
doses of oxcarbazepine
